editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Country Innocence: OR, THE Chamber-Maid TURN'D QUAKER. A COMEDY. With Alterations and Amendments.
As it is now ACTED at the THEATRE-ROYAL.
Written by JOHN LEANERD.
Licenſed, Apr. 6. 1677. Roger L'Eſtrange.
LONDON: Printed for Charles Harper, at the Flower-de-luce, over againſt St. Dunſtan's-Church in Fleet-ſtreet. 1677.

div.head: To his Honoured Friend Sir FRANCIS HINCHMAN.
div.p: IN my juvenile Years, when I had the Honour of being your School-fellow, you not only encourag'd my Fancy, but gave me ſuch Inſtructions, as I may boldly ſay, rais'd me to this Height of Preſumption; and although I dare not reckon my ſelf amongſt the Number of thoſe who daily Rival each other for their Indear'd Mrs. Laureat, yet I durſt preſume in the defence of my Country Innocence, to put in for a ſmall ſhare of that Great Glory, eſpecially ſince uſher'd into th' World under your Noble Patronage. That ſhe will meet in this lewd Age with a thouſand Inconveniencies, and ſevere Cenſures, ſome of which may, perhaps, blaſt her Virgin Purity; yet being under your Protection, I make no doubt, will arm her ſo againſt th' Aſſaults of Malice, that ſhe need no more fear the Envy of a Private Cenſurer, than on the Stage ſhe did the Honour of her Royal Auditors.

It was a happineſs I did not hope for to have her Cauſe try'd by Majeſty and Goodneſs; but ſince you ſtill were happy in all your Undertakings, I made no doubt (you Applauding th' effect of a few lazy hours) but Fortune would ſave me from that ſevere Damnation, the Critick's Noiſe and Nonſenſe: Though Arrogance, and Impudence, are an Author's chief dependency, yet Modeſty and Baſhfulneſs ſhall proclaim how much I fear the Rigor of this Cenſorious Age.

Sir, I am ſenſible, I come far ſhort, both of Merit and thoſe Commendations, you were pleas'd to beſtow upon me, ſince this trifling piece, I'm ſure can merit neither; How-ere it muſt needs be much to my ſatisfaction to have acquir'd the honour of your love and liking, and as this is the firſt I ever ventur'd to undertake, I hope it will not be the laſt you will do me the honour to Protect.

Self-Love in Poetry is much like Self-Affection in a Woman, who ſhall communicate with her Glaſs a whole day together, and never find (though ſhe be moſt deform'd) the leaſt Object that may proclaim her Odious.

After I had begun this Piece, and had finiſhed the two firſt Acts, I was doubtful whether I ſhou'd make any farther progreſſion, till by fortune,
you came in and gave me ſuch good Encouragement, I flew to make an End: Which makes me ſay with Homer:
Inſpir'd with Friendſhip, and your good Advice,
I ſtrove to pleaſe the Age, though nere ſo nice.

And that's the hardeſt Task a man can undertake, eſpecially in this Age, where Wit conſiſts only in gawdy Cloaths, monſtrous French Dances, and dam'd dull Machines. A Play cannot be made without a Painter, nor expect Applauſe unleſs your gentile French-man teaches their Feet more Nonſenſe, than their Tongues that day can utter; thoſe are the Toys now Pleaſe.

But for you, who underſtand the very ſoul of Plays, and can by the Perſon gueſs at his Works, were pleas'd to like this Antient way of Writing, and though I have not thoſe taking Graces which the World admires, yet you were pleas'd to like my Country Innocence, in its homely dreſs, as well as thoſe fine Plays compos'd of Noiſe and Ornament.

Sir, I keep you by my Impertinence from your more ſerious Studies, and from that which you may better like than theſe rude Lines. Yet I hope as you have hitherto incourag'd me, you will not now condemn him who writ more to pleaſe you than himſelf, hoping by that means to Ingratiate my ſelf more into your favour than ever, and without offence, preſume to write my ſelf,

closer.signed: the moſt Conſtant Admirer of You and your Merits, Your Servant to Command, JOHN LEANERD.

div.head: TO THE READERS.
div.p: YOu may imagine, That I am vain-glorious in thus Crouding a Play into the World, before 'twas ſcarce acquainted with it; but when you, as well as I, know the Reaſon, you will not blame my haſt. I think there is ſcarce any that us'd to ſee Plays, but went (nay crouded) to help a new Author into th' World, and I think (without Oſtentation) never was Houſe more throng'd; what Applauſe it had, I'll leave to your Cenſuring, not daring to blaſe my own Merits. The firſt, ſecond, and other times it was Acted, I think loſt me no Credit, but as Fortune never for a Continuance ſtays with one perſon, ſo at length ſhe Jaded me, robbing me of the Honour of my Plays continuance for that time; by a Miſchance which hapned to one, whoſe Part was too conſiderable to be quickly ſtudied.
This I thought fit to acquaint the World withal, that it might take off thoſe calumnious and falſe Reproaches, the Criticks of this Age would throw upon me.

But Gentlemen, to you I ſpeak, who judge more for Affection, than for Juſtice, be not ſevere to One ne're writ before; uſe him but as kindly as you do your Miſtris, the firſt Night of your Enjoyment, and then I need not fear, had I a thouſand Enemies.

And you, ſage ſerious Judges, who damn all Plays this Age has yet produc'd, learn to be kind to one you never ſaw; Applaud him, though in whiſpers, and he'll ſtrive, ere long, to give you thanks in that Degree, which you moſt wiſh, and he doth moſt deſire, that is, in once more bringing before you the Works,

closer.signed: of one, who deſires to be your Obliging Servant, JOHN LEANERD.

lg.l: AS a young Girl that's newly come to Town,
And in her Ruſſet wanders up and down,
Ventures her Maiden-head for half a Crown,
So our young Poet with his firſt Deſign
Hazards his Credit for a Pint of Wine.
Honour's grown wondrous cheap, as well as Plays;
I Gad, both are worth nothing, now adays,
Since ev'ry Fop preſumes to wear the Bays.
Never was Wit ſo much abus'd before;
The Trade's grown common, and the Jilting Whore's
Debauch'd in ev'ry Street, at ev'ry Door.
You men of Wit, of Honour, and Renown,
Thoſe little Fops, the Monſters of the Town,
To be thought witty, with their Noiſe cry down.
But let that paſs; Damn all thoſe men of ſenſe,
Whoſe Wit conſiſts in Noiſe and Impudence.
Our Fate's ſo hard, and you are ſo ſevere,
To hiſs and rail, is all your Bus'neſs here.
The Viſor-Masks you mind, and not the Wit;
Talk Bawdy, and Debauch your ſelves i' th' Pit.
Then in a rage, as if your Wit was ſcar'd,
You damn the Play, though ſcarce a Word you heard.
Pray let Good Nature, now that ſlighted Miſs,
Whiſper the Wits, and beg 'em not to hiſs.
For thoſe whoſe Wit conſiſts in gawdy Cloaths,
In vamping Old, and ſtudying New Oaths,
Ile leave, until their want of Noiſe and Senſe
Damn 'em beyond their own Impertinence.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Lady Lovely, a Widow, — Mrs. Marſhall.
Margaret and Gillian, Daughters to Thraſhard. —Sarah Cook.

div.head: THE Country Innocence. OR, THE Chamber-maid turn'd QUAKER.
ACT. I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver and Mr. William.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: BElieve me, Sir, I have told you what you Worſhip may moſt certainly truſt to.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: May I not ſpeak with her?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You know my place— there's no more hope from the deep pit of Grief, to raiſe in her any conceit of Love, than there's to raiſe her Husband up again from the cold Bed he ſleeps in. Take this for all: My Lady, Sir, has vow'd to live and die a Widow— So I leave you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Is't poſſible? Well, I know not! but if ſhe has made ſuch a Vow, and keep it! to find out ſuch another and a Phoenix, is but an equal labour.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Save you Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: As much to you, kind Mr. Raſh.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: You have been with the Widow, this melancholy Lady already. Give you much joy of your fair hopes, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir. Oliv.
sp.p: As much to your ſelf Sir, kind Mr. Raſh.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p:
I'le hope as much as I can, though you are a Knight, and I but an honeſt Citizen: A Mercer is a Merchant, and will
look for good Ware for his money.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: If he ſhould enter now; I'le ſee the iſſue.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: You know my coming to ſpeak with your Lady Mr. William:

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: But ſhe's not at leaſure to hear you.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I hope you do but Jeſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, in Earneſt.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: But I'le not tak't in Earneſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: But you muſt.
sp.stage: Offers to go to the door.
sp.p: Though you are a Citizen, you are not free of this Hall, and therefore muſt have no admittance.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Give you much Joy of your fair hopes. Another—

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Save you Gentlemen: how is't Mr. Raſh?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: As well as may be Mr. Pluſh.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: You have got the ſtart of me, I ſee that Gentlemen; a Suit brought me home this Morning made me ſtay ſomewhat the longer; but my Taylors Bill, like a Woodcock as he is, ſhall be ſo much the longer a paying—you have been within?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: In our time.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: I mean this Morning.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: But the Lady means no ſuch thing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: We heard of your Worſhips new Suit, and would not go in before it.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: I'le lead the way then.

div.p: Mr. William good Morrow, good Morrow ſweet Mr. William: and wheres the Lady? you ſee we come to come to her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, you are too haſty.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Why, is not the Lady up yet?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Not for you to take her down Sir. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: This Fellow's ſawcy.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Minds not your Worſhips new Suit; but we muſt be content.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: We may be patient, Sir, but not content; for nothing contents me but the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Who have we here, Mr Pluſh, Mr. Raſh? I dare be ſo bold as embrace you two— but my Noble Sir, my SIR of a Thouſand per Annum.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Why, I can be a Knight an I liſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: And I can be Knight an I liſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Dub'd with the City Dagger— then Raſh would be raſh indeed: you come to ſee my Siſter? Las good hearts! Methinks the Gates of themſelves ſhould fly ope to ſuch brave men as you are.

sp.speaker: Sir. Oliv.
sp.p: You have the Old Heart ſtill, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: The Young Heart ſtill Sir Oliver— the Mad Heart, the Merry Heart— the Light Heart, with the Candle of Conceit burning in it as bright as Lucifer, Heſper and Veſper: you have not been within? I'le turn out this pair of Aſſes, and then you ſhall ſee my Siſter. I perceive by your melancholy looks, my melancholy, pettiſh, peeviſh Siſter is not at this time to be ſpoke withal. 'Tis ſuch a fooliſh Thing;—ſhe knows not Worth, nor how to entertain't: ſuffice it Gentlemen, I do; and ſhall not go behind her back to let her know your Merits: and in a juſt proportion to that Merit, that maſs of Merit, you ſhall find her favour: So Mr. Puſh and Mr. Raſh I ſhall deſire you to leave us.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: You'l remember.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Shall I remember (Gentlemen) to eat, to ſleep, to drink? then I'le remember you—

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Then? — when Sir Robert?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: When I am aſleep—awake I ſhall never mind 'em, for their Worſhips are hardly worth it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Yes in a juſt proportion to their merit.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Yes, that's juſt nothing — hang 'em Glow-Worms, hang um.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Here's another Rub in our Alley, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: A Tenants Son of mine— and how does my honeſt Abraham?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: The better your good Worſhip is well Sir; I was to ſeek your good Worſhip, at your Right Worſhipful Houſe Sir; but miſſing you there, I rejoyce I have met with you here.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Why? what's the matter? Abr'am, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: In the way of Love, as they ſay, from my Father and my Siſter, and my t'other Siſter too— you know who I mean Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Thy ſcolding Siſter?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: You are in the right.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: And how does Margaret my Pretty Tenant?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: That Pretty One is pretty well Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Remember me to her by this.
Within this day or two at the fartheſt I ſhould breath a Gelding; it may be that way, and viſit my Pretty Tenant.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Long may your Worſhips Gelding breath, and your Worſhipful Self alſo. I am in haſte Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Take your own time, Good Abram.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Thank your good Worſhip Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: I have done your Patience wrong,
Indeed I have; but the beſt that lies in me to right it, you ſhall command. Now to my Siſter.
Now where's my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: She's within Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Come then, let's to her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You muſt pardon me: ſhe's ſo retir'd to Solitude, and ſet ſo deep in grief, that till her ſighs and tears will give her leave to entertain ſuch worthy Viſitants, 'tis her ſtrict command that no man enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Not my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Your ſelf, Sir, if you would not ſwell her grief too big for her faint Breaſt to carry; give her way, a little time may change her.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: 'Tis enough—you ſee Sir Oliver:

sp.speaker: Sir. Oliv.
sp.p: Your love, Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.l: But, as her Gentleman diſcreetly ſaid;
A little time may change her: We muſt ſtill
In ſuch a kind humour win a Womans will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Come, thou mak'ſt ſuch a matter of nothing.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Nothing, do you call it? I know not, but I'm ſure I feel ſomething— 'tis almoſt kicking ripe already.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Almoſt kicking ripe? — come, come, thou art a Chambermaid ſtill: — and I prithee what's this but a Work that belongs to the Chamber?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Well, you will not marry me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: And hazard my place with my Lady—and yet now I think on't—I will—

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Marry me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: To ſome of my Old Acquaintance: there are Hundreds in the City that have ſwallow'd worſe bits than thou art.

div.stage: Enter Lady Lovely in Mourning vail'd, Lady Mallory and Old Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Urge me no more; but let the Love you ſeem to ſhow be expres'd in Words, that better ſuit with ſuch a Robe as this, and my immutable reſolve.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Then I perſwade in vain, yet whil'ſt you live (incompaſs'd thus with ſorrow and ſolitude) a Widow you ſeem to voice to the ill cenſuring World ſome imperfection in your ſelf. 'Tis true, you loſt a worthy Gentleman, my ſelf a Noble Brother; yet if you lov'd him living, love him dead; then I am ſure you'l caſt all ſorrow off, and ceaſe to wrong your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: Mark you that now?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: 'Tis the beſt Tomb-ſtone you can lay upon him; the nobleſt Monument you can erect; and to that Monument an Epitaph, ſhall make him live for ever.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: Law you there now! — ſhall make him live for ever! — you are not dumb tho? — are you?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Would thou wert, or I had loſt my hearing; I can wiſh nothing ſo adverſe to me, as your Tongues: and therefore if your Viſits bring with them nothing but theſe perſwaſions—

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Keep away.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p:
Nay, as ſpeak't as think it. — Here's a coyle
for a Husband, I have had for my own part— 1-2-3-4, and yet if the fifth come up handſomely to me, I know what I I know, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: How! Five!

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: Fifteen, if the Deſtinies had ſo decreed it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Madam, there be Suitors below to ſee you. Mr. Raſh the Mercer— one Pluſh a humorous Gallant, and a ſpick and ſpan new Suitor a Country Gentleman, one Mr. Gregory Dwindle.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: Spruce Mr. Raſh I know.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: And I, Mr. Pluſh, a notable humorous Coxcomb: but what's that Gregory?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Unknown to me; but believe me, together they make up a delicate Motion.— Is your Ladiſhip pleaſed to ſee um?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Preſent your Motion ſomewhere elſe, my Griefs give way to no ſuch lightneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: I'le tell 'em what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Pray ſtay a little, I know 〈…〉 ors are but empty things; not worth our ſerious thoughts yet Siſter, pray let um Enter, let 'em look upon you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Still your deſire's my trouble.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: Come, come, pray: you are ſo melancholy.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Why, their mirth will be a means to Cure you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Kill me rather.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: Go, bid 'em come.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Bid 'em be gone.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Nay, then you are too Cruel: Stay.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Siſter, if you know no other Merriment, than what you raiſe from my vexation, take it, I will not hinder your Deſires; pray take it.

sp.speaker: Old. Gentle.
sp.p: You will not leave us, will you?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p:
And go mew your ſelf up in your Chamber, like a cloyſtered Nun, there waſte away your tedious Hours in ſighs, and ſpend the Day in groans: for my part, I am altogether for Mirth and open Air; a Priſon can't content me— but Siſter,
before you go, let me intreat one favour of you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: That in your abſence you'd be pleas'd to let your Waiting Gentlewoman appear in your Apparel: 'tis but ſlipping off this upper Garment, and this Mourning Vaile, and ſhe's my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: How? my Bab, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: It will be ſport to us, and to your ſelf a rare advantage, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Though pleaſure be no pleaſure to this Boſome, ſince you propoſe the acquittance of that trouble, your deſire's granted.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: But be ſpeedy then with your directions for her carriage in it.
sp.stage: Ex. Lady Lovely, Bab, and Mr. William.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee ſuch a ſelf-will'd Thing as this is? a Widow this two months, and yet not hear of a Suitor.

div.stage: Enter Mr. William, Raſh, Pluſh, and Gregory.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: The Gentlemen, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Yes indeed, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: Mr. Raſh!

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Your Servant, Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Mr. Pluſh!

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: My name is Pluſh. Maſter my Title, and Sir a Title that may be.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: And my name is Gregory.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Fop — the ſound is out of ſeaſon— but where's the Lady?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I, where's the Lady?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: We would ſee the Lady.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: I hope ſhe has done Mourning now, has ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why, does the Lady Mourn?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Indeed ſhe does.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: 'Tis a delicate thing to Mourn.— Well, an my Father would but die once!—would we could ſee this Lady.

div.stage: Enter Bab, like Lady Lovely vailed.

sp.speaker: Old Gentle.
sp.p: You have your wiſh already.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Beauteous Lady.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Moſt beautious Lady.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Moſt beautiful Lady that may be: for yet I ſee no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Thy Eyes are veil'd with Ignorance, or elſe, through this thin veil, thou might'ſt as we, — behold matter of admiration! — you'l vouchſafe; — not yet.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Alas! —upon their captive Heart, my ſorrows yet have ſet too ſtrong a Guard for ſuch delights to enter.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: I could wiſh, that Conqueror of thy Heart and all his Guard were viſible, that I might challenge them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: I marry Sir, that were a challenge indeed.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Methinks I could—do—

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: What do you think you could do Sir?

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: O — my moſt delicate Lady!

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Do his moſt delicate Lady; a terrible Do indeed.

sp.speaker: Old'Gentlew.
sp.p: Well Lady; if this be the man ſhall have you, you ſhall have a Man I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: If I be the Man that ſhall have her, ſhe ſhall have a Man I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: But he's a fighting man.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: A fighting man? Let him play at the Ancient Weapon, an he were a Fencing Man, Il'e have about with him.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: The Ancient Weapon! — what Weapon's that?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why this.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: As Wiſe as Valiant; 'tis the Ancient Weapon indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: And why not this? —

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I am better acquainted with this.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Well, we ſhall meet?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: And meet again: tell me of fighting—Lady!

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: I ſee you are valiant Sir; — and you are happy in having ſo much Valour as you ſee attend your Beauty.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs them Worthy Gentlemen; but they muſt pardon me; — the Worth that I have loſt in my dead Husband, is ſo full and freſh upon my underſtanding: — that all elſe have but homely entertainment—and yet you are welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All three.
sp.p: For that we thank you.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: We muſt hope ſtill.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Well, and my Father would but die once! I live hope too Lady.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You ſee their Valour Sir,—and what's your Weapon?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I am no man of the Sword — I have no Weapon.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: How Sir, no Weapon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: What ſhould you do in Cupid's Fencing-School, and have no Weapon?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: There was a Time I could have croſs'd a Cudgel; and if any man ſtrike me, I have a Weapon too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: The coldeſt Flint has fire I ſee: what Weapon?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: One that is indeed all Weapons, Long Sword, Sword and Dagger, Sword and Buckler, Single Rapier and Dagger, Halbert, Half-pike, Quarter-Staff, Short Sword and Gauntlet, and that terrible Fly-flap the Fauchion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: All theſe in one?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Or one that's worth all theſe, and that in a word is the Law.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: A terrible Weapon indeed.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: There, let me firk um, and jerk 'em; there, let me ſtand upon tearms; there, let me play the Maſter, and Mr. Attorney my Uſher, and then with all the Weapons in that School have at 'em.

div.stage: Enter Sir Robert and Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: This goes heyond your Rapier, or that Ancient Weapon the Fiſt.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: We are betray'd: my Husband and Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Play the Lady a little longer, and handſomly Bab, and I'le promiſe thee a new Gown.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Come, come, we will ſpeak, and ſpeed too, my Knight of a Thouſand per Annum. Where's this Mourning Lady? What, my Madona and my Lady Littleworth! hoyday! this Covy of Coxcombs too!

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: One.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Kind Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Two.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Worthy Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p:
Three: yet never a wiſe word amongſt them. What ſtill dumb Lady? An ye were as heavy as Lead, 'twas but a light
trick of you to deny acceſs to ſuch a man as this is, and allow it to ſuch Minncks as theſe are, s'death I could kick 'em out o'th' Room, and be angry with you, though you are my Wives Siſter, for lodging ſuch baſeneſs within you.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: Why, you are not out of your Wits, are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: You have no Wit to be out of, Gentlemen: you are all Hobby-horſes, an it pleaſe you to leave the houſe now, and come again— when you are ſent for — you ſhall be — heartily glad to be welcome?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: You ſee his humour, Gentlemen, pray leave us.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why? but I hope—

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Not one word more an ye love me.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Nay, then—I would I were but gone once.
sp.stage: Exeunt manent Sir Rob. Sir Oliv. Lady, Mall. Bab. and Mr. William.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Come, take my Counſel and forget him.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Still looking downwards to your Husbands Grave?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: To thoſe that wear ſo ſad a Suit as this, the Grave's the Glaſs they uſe to deck um by. Pray give me leave.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Prethee look up a little; — I can ſhew thee a Glaſs, that ſhall reflect no ſuch affrighted ſhadows.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Oh! Oh! Oh! —

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Excellent Mourning Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: The Nuptial Knot binds Loving Paires together, only for term of Life, has no extent o're the Divoice of Death.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Pray, pray, no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: That only binds the Living to the Living, and not the Living to the Dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: That fleſh that hath Soul within it; the endowments and excellencies, bounteous Heav'n beſtowes to that, has nothing but the frightful ſhape, and the cold Figure of a Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Yet this; whil'ſt you doat upon your Husbands duſt, you do (ſweet Lady) doat upon your Torment.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: You have my Reſolution, ſo pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And you be buried in your Husbands Grave: I ſee my Suit muſt dye too.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Yes, and let it, let it for ever dye to her, and live to one deſelves it better. Come, I'le bring thed, though ſhe be my Wives Siſter, to one that's younger, fairer, richer, and it may be — honeſter too.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: How, Sir Robert, Honeſter!

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Yes, honeſter; an ſhe proſtrate her ſelf to a Set of Moris-Dancers—and neglect ſuch a Caeſar as this is! Come Sir Oliver, let's away.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Nay, but heark you, heark you Sir Robert, and worthy Sir Oliver, that you may ſee this Lady, is not the Woman that you take her for; look, do you know this Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir. Rob.
sp.p: How, Bab?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: My Ladies Chambermaid!

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: A trick of mirth they put upon the Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Were you my Lady?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: So your Lady would have it, Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: My Lady Bab—how like you this Sir Oliver?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: This Change has put ſome life into me Sir; and I muſt tell you, better'd my opinion both of the Ladies Wiſdom, and her Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: But heark you Wife, may we not ſee my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Faith, yet her temper is not as we'd have it; but we ſhall win her by degrees, and turn her melancholy to a ſprightly humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Then I'le not doubt my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Come, Sir Oliver, mean time we'l ſee what mirth my Houſe can yield to entertain you with, — A ha! my Girl! Why, ſuch a Wench is worth her weight in Pearl!
sp.stage: Exeunt manent Bab and Mr. Will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Well, thou haſt play'd my Lady like a Lady:

q.l: I have a trick from this Conceit to do,
Shall make us ſport, and help thy ſwelling too.

div.head: ACT. II.
div.stage: Enter Old Thraſhard and Margaret dreſt Genteelly.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: SIR, I have ſpoke my danger.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p:
A dangerous caſe, believe me; and yet methinks there's no great danger neither: for, ſay a man offer to blow thee up
with Love-powder; if his Train lie ſo open, you may ſee it: you have the Wit, I hope, to ſhun it,—h'an't you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I have done hitherto.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: And do'ſt thou fear thou can'ſt hold out no longer?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Sir, I do not.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: That's well, but to the point: what is he? do I know him?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes, if you know Sir Robert Malory your Landlord, Father.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Sir Robert! He aim againſt thy Chaſtity? has he beſtow'd upon thy Infancy that care and coſt that he has done; maintain'd thee 'mongſt his own, and for this? is this the beſt you can affoard him?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No — Father, for theſe ſhould I forgot to pay, the moſt obſequious Duties I can tender, 'twere juſt in Heav'n I ſhould forget my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Had this been ſpoke of any other man, I might have lent an ear to't: — but, Sir Robert! Noble Sir Robert! — that brave man, Sir Robert! our bounteous Benefactor! Say he has ſcatter'd ſome words i'th' way of merriment, ſome pleſant, idle—wanton— what d'ye call it? ſprinkled a little Bawdry in his ſpeech? as Courtiers may, elſe they are no men of Faſhion. That cuts not off a Maidenhead — Nay, perchance the Merriment that you interpret Luſt, was his meer love to Vertue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Vertue!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Yes: — 'tis my Conceit, that all his Talk, his Letters, and all the Gifts he ſent you, were employ'd i'th' way of Tryal, not to make thee naught; but ſo to ſound thy goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Think you ſo? I'le think ſo too then Father.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: This is fine, you have the golden time on't.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What golden time? you'l ſtill be ſcolding.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Scolding! Marry come up Mrs. Jinny-finny; we can't ſpeak to you now, but 'tis ſcolding; well, I ſay little.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Nothing at all were better.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: But I'le ſay ſomething; has a Woman a Tongue to ſay nothing?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Prethee be patient Siſter.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Yes I waun't you, I muſt Waſh, Scowre, Brew and Bake, and do this thing, and do that thing, and do every thing, while ſuch a Beautiful Blouſe as you are, muſt ſit ſtill and do nothing.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Why, do'ſt thou not ſee her at work?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: At work! a great piece of work adeed Law! Prick, Prick, Prick, as if ſhe had nothing in the World to mind, but Prick, Prick, Prick; but 'tis no matter, 'tis but my hard Fortune; I am a Fool indeed, and ſo you make me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What, what, a Show'r after this Peale of Thunder? Nay, do not cry good Gillian.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Oh! Father, Father!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Now Boy, what News with you now?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Brave News Father; News of the brave Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Purſue me ſtill — Good Father give me leave while he is come in and gone again.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What leave?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: To abſent my ſelf, but in ſome Neighbours houſe: I have a trick to paſs him — You may tell him I'm gone to London.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: When I have told him already you'r here in the Parlor a ſewing.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Come, you'r a Baggage, a fooliſh Baggage to injure with ſuch frivolous ſuſpitions, a Gentleman of his repute and goodneſs: come, let me hear no more on't.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Sirſter Gillian, I have the rareſt News for you.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: For me, 'tis well: and what News have you got for me Sir?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Skipping News, lepping News, tripping News.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: How! Dancing Brother Abram? Dancing!

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Dancing, Prancing, Advancing; Nay, 'tis a Match: a Match upon a Wager.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: A Match! who be they?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Why, all the Maids of our Town Edmonton, and all the mad Wenches of Waltam.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: A Match, and leave me out! When, when is't Brother?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Marry, e'en this Morning, they are now going to't helter skelter.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And leave me out! Where Brother, where?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Why, there Siſter Gillian, there, at our own door almoſt; cloſe by the May-pole; on the Green there: heark, you may hear them hither.

l.hi: SHALL the Laſſes and Lads, to be merry all Day,
To Frolick and Kiſs, to be bucksome and Gay,
Meet all on the Green
To chuſe out a Queen,
And leave out the bliſs of their mortal Eſtate;
The Laſs that's all Ayrie, and longs for the Fate,
That Fate which is common to thoſe who can tell
The Bleſſings of Youth, that in Pleaſure excel.

div.p: And I be not One!

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Thou't never be Two, I think; for on my Conſcience there is no man that knows her has valoir enough to come near her.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Why, well ſaid Girl, keep but that reſolution

div.p: And let his purpoſes be what they can, they cannot hurt thee. Look, he's come already.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Good morrow Tenant: Good morrow Beautiful Tenant.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: As much to my Worthy Landlord.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: As much to my Worthy Landlord.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: My Tenant Abram — God-a-mercy good Tenant Abram. I want your welcome Fair One.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Had this been ſpoke with Smiles upon thy Cheek, I durſt have ſworn the Syllables had been the language of thy Heart. What, ſtill ſo adverſe to my Pleaſure? Tenant, and my young Tenant, ſhall I crave the Room? I have ſomething to deliver from my Lady, that ſhe would have a Secret to the Ear of ev'ry one but Margaret.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: The Room? our poverty poſſeſſes nothing Sir, but what is yours; you may command it. Come—

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: I ſmell my Landlord: but— no more words but mum.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Still, ſtill this cloud upon thy brow, ſweet Peg, you know my mind.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: And you know mine Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: I mean, I love you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Not half ſo well as I love you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Love me! then there's ſome hope again. Aſide.
Let's ſee how willingly you'l yield to my Embraces. How! fly 'em Peg? ſuch a thing deny'd, how canſt thou ſay thou loveſt me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, Sir: I love you in your Name, your Reputation, the Dignity you carry in your years, — in your Lady. I love you Sir, i'th' fair Benevolence you owe her Vertues. In a word, Sir Robert, I love you in that Purity, that ſhall when Death threatens, make you look boldly on him. Thus I love you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: This is not that I look'd for; do you remember your Father is my Tenant?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Sir he is.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Nay, ſince you urge it, let me tell you Minion, he's not my Tenant neither, but my Beadſman.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: And like an humble Beadſman in his Prayers remembers all your Charity.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: He does, but you forget it Fair One.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then let Hea'vn when we Petition the reward it merits forget me too.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Is't not forgetfulneſs, when all the Love the tender cares and coſt, that from thy Infancy, to this ripe Growth, I have beſtow'd upon you, cannot gain me ſuch a requeſt as this.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: This! Alas! your greateſt gain's in loſing: Nay, I'le tell you, the Love, the Care, that Coſt, that Noble Breeding, which ſeems to you a winning Argument, is my beſt Argument againſt you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, Sir, the Education, that fair Breeding you have beſtow'd upon my Poverty has made me what I am, and plentifully furniſhed my Soul with all that beſt adorns her, that whatſoever is in oppoſition to it, is —

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Your Luſt, Sir Robert: I am bold, but yet can kneel to beg your mercy for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p:
What? ſhe imagines Water to my Flame, is Oyl t'increaſe it. The more ſhe puts me off, the more ſhe pulls me to her.
Come, come riſe, though you be ſo unkind, I can forgive you: I muſt not look at firſt to have ſo great a happineſs, as that we aim at, but muſt uſe degrees, and then—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: For this time Peg, I'le leave thee: What? leave thee, and leave thee nothing? that were foul play indeed: there; nay, take it: indeed you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Indeed I will not Sir; for any ſervice I can do you, your Favour's price ſufficient. No, not yet? I ha't. How I forget my Duty? Here ſo long, and ne're a Chair to eaſe you? Abram, Brother; pray pardon me, Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: How, a Chair? kinder and kinder ſtill: Nothings like Gifts to gain a Womans will.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Come, come, a Chair there for Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: She pities your long ſtanding Sir; but I have a Chair almoſt at my Fingers end.
Look you Sir, will it pleaſe you Bum this Cuſhion.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: How, Bum it Tenant?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Yes: Bum it Landlord—look you Sir, o' this faſhion.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Come, you'l be fooliſh.
You know my mind, bring 'em in.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: An I bring 'em not in, let Sir Robert kick me out.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Come, fit down; nay, yet a little nearer; you need not be afraid to ſit by me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I am not Sir, as long as you are virtuous.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: I'le be as virtuous as an Alderman, and abhor all— How now? what's that?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Muſick, Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Rot on their Fiddle and their Fiddle-ſtrings, thou art my Muſick.

div.stage: Enter a Morris: after the Morris this Song is ſung.

l.hi: CHarming Beauty, you alone
Deſerve the Glories of a Throne;
Such a Queen we Swains admire,
And each Breaſt is fill'd with Fire,
And yet vain is our deſire.

lg.l: Cho. Though to Love and fond Joyes we our thoughts do prefer,

l.hi: Yet none can be worthy, not worthy of her.

lg.head: II.

l.hi: Thou Queen of our Joyes, and thou Goddeſs of Bliſs,
Though the Charmes are too great to be mention'd in this,

lg.l: Let a ſmile, ſince you'r made the bright Lady of May,,

l.hi: Inſtead of a frown all our Services pay;
For ſince Frown's a Fate, no ſeverer can be,
Your Smiles can rejoyce us and ſet us all free.

lg.l: Cho. Free, we are free from all trouble and Strife,

l.hi: And this day is the beſt, and the happieſt of Life.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You ſee we ſweat to make your Worſhip merry; how do you like our paſtime?

sp.speaker: Sir. Rob.
sp.p: I like it ſo well, I could wiſh you were further off with it.

sp.speaker: Maids.
sp.p: Have we this for our kindneſs, Sir Robert?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Marry come up, Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Shall I intreat you leave the Room.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: The Room?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: So ſhe ſaid, but I know ſhe means no ſuch matter, only a trick; tell her you wonnot go.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Pray leave the Room.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: We wonnot.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Wonnot?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: No: We were ſent for in, and we will not go out again yet. Out? Marry gip there, ne're a good Inch of a thouſand. Fidlers ſtrike, I'le ſtrike you elſe; and cut your begging Bow-ſtrings.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: I muſt be gone, I ſee; theſe miſerable impudent Stallions will over-run me elſe. Farewell, nothing grieves me but—

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: But what Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: We cannot — kiſs at parting—Farewel.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Come, we'l have the t'other bout, and then—

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay, we'l have no more at this time, here's enough.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: For you, but not enough for me; you ſhall command me, ſhall you?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay, be not angry Siſter, 'tis no Command, but my Intreat—Good Siſter.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Well, ſince you intreat me, and ſeem to know your betters, you ſhall have your will for once. Fidlers lead the way, and Wenches follow your Leader.
sp.stage: Ex. Fidlers playing, Gillian and the Morris-dancers following dancing.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Leader! if ſcolding were fighting, what a Leader would'ſt thou be? you'd bring 'em on with a Powder.

div.p: O! Father, Father!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Ne're a wiſe word for a Wager: Sir Robert's gone I ſee.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he is.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: And how do'ſt find him? I do not think the man, that your ſuſpicion ſeem'd to make him.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You have a good Opinion of him Father, and I'le not ſtand to croſs it.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Come, you'r a peeviſh Thing, and I'm afraid have been diſtaſteful to him.
Conſider all is his, we muſt be wiſe, Since by his frowns we fall; and favours riſe.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver, Bellingham, and the Lady Lovely.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Madam, can the Heart thus feed (like Vultures) on it ſelf, and bear the torment? for ſuch is Grief, ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, as I am, pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Leave you to be out Rivall'd by the Dead!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To me he lives, and ev'ry hour appears ſo really my own, as all th' Embraces of a Second Match would ſtick upon me like the Leperous Stains of Luſt and baſe Adultery, and by this pray underſtand the vainneſs of your ſuit, and ſo conclude it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: No more: I have my Anſwer, and am Married.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: As you are Madam, to my Self alone, no other earthly Creature; yet my Love Petitions, that if e're hereafter, (ſince now you are ſo firm) you find an alteration in your Soul, to fancy Wedlock, that I, I your Servant may, for that ſecond Happineſs to Heav'n, ſtand fair'ſt in your Election.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That ſatisfaction take, if e're I marry, it ſhall be you, that is my Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I am extaſi'd beyond the Joyes of Heav'n. If e're I know the Sweets of Hymen, I muſt find 'em here. So, we are married now, and in this Joy I leave you.

div.stage: As he is going Enter Sir Robert Mallory, Lady Mallory and Old Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Here's a Rub in your way a while, my brave Knight of a Thouſand per Annum; and how do'ſt find her, is ſhe coming? Ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: You ſee my Hopes ſet Smiles upon my Cheeks; let them reſolve you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert.
sp.p: I underſtand you: but when's the Day?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Nay, queſtion that no further, we ſhall talk on't.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: I, I, when a thing's done, tis done.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: You'd feign be Doing too then?

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: Would I not? do you think I am all dead fleſh? —I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Now Mr. William, what good tidings now Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: My News is, worthy Sir, that Mullinex the ſtout Sea Captain is return'd, and yeſterday was ſeen on the Change.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: The ſame Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Oliv.
sp.p: How is't—ha—you loſe Colour Madam?

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: Lady.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Siſter.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Beſhrew the Name, and Owner of the Name, which has diſturbed you—What's that Name to you?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, nothing but my Trouble.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p:
A troubleſome Captain indeed Sir: a Suitor to her once, and Rival to her Husband Sir James Lovely; but miſs'd the
mark he aimd at; he ſhot fair, but Lovely fairer; upon which he went to Sea; where he has been three Years, but's now return'd: and hearing (as it ſeems) that ſhe's a Widow, he'd renew his Suit, give her a Broad-ſide, Sir, and Board her; nay, let me tell you, you have a hot Rival, one that will Quarrel, Fight, and by my Faith— I am half afraid of Danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: If he be not all Valour and no Judgement, I fear none: but what ſo e're he be, I'le be but what becomes me.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: It may be ſome new Beauty has him now; ſome Foraign Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Or it may be Siſter, this time of Service in the Wars, has made him only in Love with Fighting.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: More Vexation.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: This Mountain brings forth a Mouſe! have we talk't all this while of a Captain, and now muſt be troubled with Coxcombs?

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: The Gods protect you Lady.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: Thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: I ſpoke to that ſweet Beauty.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: But I muſt ſpeak to you Sir, for you ſee ſhe has other employment. Pray ſtand aſide a little.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: If I muſt, I ſhall attend her leaſure.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: You muſt attend her too Sir: do you not ſee ſhe's buſie.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I would not interrupt her.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I would not interrupt her! Is that the reſolution of a Lover? let me come to her.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: But you ſhall not Sir.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Nay, if I ſhall not Sir, I will not Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Is that the Reſolution of a Lover?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: A man can do no more than he can do: but an my Father would but die once—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Make nice to me of entrance! where's the Widow? for ſo I hear ſhe is now. What, mourning ſtill? I am a bold Gameſter:
Save you all at once; all Suitors Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Sir, we are all Suitors.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Y'are a little to Raſh in that, for I am none.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Nor I neither: would I were at home.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Citizen, and a Mercer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I know you by this Wheele, Turns him round. You have a great many Bags, and a great many Buildings too Sir; but dare you for all that, preſume in the way of Matrimony, to look ſo high as a Lady?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: He that can purchaſe a Lordiſhip.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Thinks he may purchaſe a Ladiſhip: — You my Rival! Can you fight Sir?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: It may be I, it may be no, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then I'le try whether you can or no Sir.
Not a word as you love your Coxcomb.
Are you a Suitor too Sir?

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Too Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Y'are an Aſs, Sir,—can you fight?

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Fight? in a Ladies Chamber?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why? where would you fight Sir?

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Why, the truth on't is—I would fight—no where.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I thought as much, and therefore I will kick you— good Mr. Outſide of a Gentleman follow your valiant Leader.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: You will not kill him, will you?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Have you ſo much Tongue, and ne're a good Tooth, Madam Fumble?

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: Fumble, Fumble,—y'are a moſt—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Peace, an you love your old Carcaſe—peace.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You bind me to a Patience.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: One Poſt ſupport another? What are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why—I—am—a—Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Will your Arms bear you out in the Title?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: My Legs ſhall bear me out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Then you will not be beat out as they were?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I ſhould be very loath to be beaten.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: In troth I think you would Sir.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Do I look like one that would be beaten?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If you ſtay you muſt.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why, therefore I mean to be gone Sir. But if my Father would but die once.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You ſee his rudeneſs, and to prevent the danger it threatens, pray leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I will not add to his too prodigal heat, nor be cold to fear it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis my Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And mine to tarry, not offending you, with humble contradiction.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Are theſe your Suitors Madam?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A little in Jeſt, but you have paid them in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: I did but ſpeak in the way of Compaſſion, and your Lordſhip call'd me—Madam Fumble, Fumble, did I ever fumble with you Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Be wiſe in being Silent; I hear you have loſt a husband: How is't Widow?

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: You'l quarrel with her too, will ye?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You are ſo nice: I cannot Complement, kiſs your white Hand and fleer upon you. I can kiſs your Lip, hug you, and tell you I muſt lye with you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: There may be thoſe of your Acquaintance, to whom this Language would be pleaſing; but to let you know how ill't appears to me, I'le change my Room Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But you ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: You lay too rude a Violence upon the tenderneſs of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do I ſo Sir? I thank your kind remembrance. You the man? this Ladies only man Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: My deſire is you would not be uncivil.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Whatſoe're my Will produces, I can juſtifie.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: That power maintains offence, is weakneſs Sir, and has no taſte of Breeding, or of Manhood.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'le make you taſte of ſomething.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: But you ſhall not. Have we no Servants near us.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Save him; help.

div.stage: Enter Mr. William and Cut. They interpoſe between 'em.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: O! y'are wicked Captain.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What? Naked Weapons in Ladies Chamber?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Take her in, poor Lady, how ſhe's frighted!

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: My Noble Knight and Maſter!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: We have done Sir.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: And you have done, there's nothing to do; if nothing to do, the leſs to take care for; the leſs to take care for, the ſounder we ſleep; and aſleep we think no body hurt Sir. And ſo having done, I have done.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You have the advantage of me.

sp.speaker: Sir. Oliv.
sp.p: I muſt tell you, this rudeneſs better would become the Field, than ſuch a Place as this.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That you may know, I know as much as you inſtruct me to, meet me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: As good have ſaid you dare not. The Apology is pretty, all Cowards uſe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: How, Cowards?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Cowards.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: His Lunacy has ſhot its ſelf into my Bloud. A Coward! proclaime me what you call me, if I be.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You'l meet me then?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Where? Thou or I.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: O—Nay, if you break ſo violently out, I ſhall ſuſpect 'tis to prevent our Meeting; for Manhood covers ſuch Intents as theſe under a friendly ſeeming—thus—

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: I marry, Gentlemen, I like this well.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Believe me, I was jealous of worſe Matters.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: And I, ne're truſt me elſe.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You know the Place and Time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: You ſhall find, I'le forget neither.

div.stage: Enter Cut, and whiſpers Lady Mallory.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
So—now Beautious Widow:—is ſhe gone? I have no Courtſhip to purſue her with, nor will I offer it: but let me tell you, he that beſt hopes her favour, if he have it, muſt bid
fairer for it than this Sword: and ſo I'le leave you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: How is it Sir? your eyes ſpeak trouble ſtill?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Sir, if they do, 'tis only what they have from your Siſters Trouble. I muſt leave you till better hours invite me to return.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Oliver, our wayes lye both together; therefore pray permit me, Sir, to wait upon you.
sp.stage: Ex. Sir Robert and Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Is't poſſible? be ſure you raiſe not this ſuſpicion from your own Fancy; look the ground be good, the matter's weighty.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I tell you but the Voice in Edmonton, which is, that he daily Viſits this Country Innocence; whether he has enjoy'd her yet or no, I am not certain; but 'tis ſo reported.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: I will not be too eaſie to believe, nor yet too confident, I know there's Fire in ſuch a Wenches Eye, and Old dry Wood will ſoon be kindled; which if he be, I'le find a way to quench him, quench both Fires, And ſatisfie at once their looſe deſires.

div.head: Act the Third.
div.stage: Enter Threſhard with a Letter, Margaret, Gillian, and Abraham.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Sir Robert's Hand, art ſure on't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am too ſure.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: And ſent to thee laſt night?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: I by this Day was it, Father. I know it to be his Hand; what do you think of this now?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You ſee the picture of a Luſtful Heart drawn to the life.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I believe thee: yet Old Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Yes, even Old Sir Robert: who have we here, a Begger?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: An ſhe deſire any thing here, I ſhall deſire her to be gone with a vengeance: who would you ſpeak withall? — Hum—hum—ha woman.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: A poor old woman; be not offended, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: And what would'ſt thou have, poor old woman?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My buſineſs is to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To me, what is't?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: I, I, what is't?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Though I may ſpeak it; ſince you fall into cauſleſs ſuſpicions of me, either hear me as I am willing to preſent it to you, or as I am I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay pray ſtay—Good Father, leave us.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Take your own courſe; —nay—nay, come you'd fain be ſcolding: on or I'll ſet you forward.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now to this private buſineſs; what is't?

sp.speaker: Mal.
Mar.
sp.p: If no foul end attend it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Tis a fair offer for that ſhort delight the Gentleman would purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You have not nam'd the man.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: It is Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir Robert Malory?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The ſame. I might renew your memory by relating his bounties to your father; and by thoſe you cannot chuſe but gueſs he loves you, Fair one. Witneſs this, this noble Prize; nay look upon it, 'tis a fair one, Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yet much too poor to bribe an Angel to impurity. Go bear 'em back again, and tell thy Maſter the luſtful Knight that ſent 'em, Where we rate our Chaſtity above our Life, we will not ſell it for ſuch Toys as theſe are.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How! ſuch Toys—I dare be bold to tell you, in this act you do not onely loſe this Golden Offer, but Happineſs for ever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yet more vexation. I will not call thee Woman, for a Woman would never labour thus t'infect the Name with ſuch a ſin as this is. Father, Siſter, for Heavens ſake help me. Father, Brother, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How now, Girl? why, what's the matter? ha?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Examine her. But ſhe perchance may tell you what ſhe does is her duty, and that to make our poor and barren Fortunes freghtful with a Golden Showre.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Golden Showre.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: O rare! an thou canſt do that, Old Woman, long mayſt thou rain I beſeech thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Father, you may believe me, for ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A Bawd.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: A Bawd?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, though the Brow of ſuch a one be Braſs, ſhe dares not contadict it: ſhe's no leſs, and her imployment from Sir Robert

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How? come come take heed.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: What ſhould ſhe take heed of? An ſhe be a Bawd ſhe is a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: That's certain, were her Bawdſhip imployed amongſt Ladies.—But ſhe ſhall ride in Triumph: now Tobacco and Aqua vitae burn thee.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Now the ſtinking ſweat upon thee and thy painted Journy-women.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: How many Noſes do you think have been loſt in your Bawdſhips ſervice?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: How many Coaches have you bawdifi'd?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: How long have you run on in this ſin? How often have the Coachmen and Horſes been whipp'd for your pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Was this Sir Robert's bounty? Baſe, baſe woman; but we'll reward your labour.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: You loſe a Daughter of me elſe.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: And an Abram of me I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I'll go get an Officer, Abram provide a Cart.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: And let me alone for a Baſon.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Has Love and Bounty this reward?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, and the beſt it merits: Away, thou art a Devildreſt in ſhape of Woman.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And thou an Angel. Now I have found thy goodneſs.
Know me better.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My ever worthy Lady.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Come, no more: thou ſeeſt the purpoſe of this poor Diſguiſe, therefore fear nothing here. Nay, you muſt take it, ſince that which ſeem'd to be the hire of Luſt ſhall now be the reward of Vertue: but you muſt imploy't as I direct you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Do but direct, and if I fail in any thing injoyn'd, let your diſpleaſure puniſh me ſeverely.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: This is all; againſt my Husbands coming (for I'm ſure he will not long be from thee;) with this and more that I'll ſupply thee with, trim up this homely Cottage and your ſelf; it is my pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'T muſt then be mine to ſerve it.

div.stage: Enter Thr. Gill. Abr. Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I have told you what ſhe is, Mr. Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: A Bawd.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: All over—we'll not bate you an Ace, Mr. Conſtable; and therefore have a care you do Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I have been amongſt Whores and Bawds too before now, and I think I have tickled them ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: I think ſo too: A Conſtable, what whore dares deny him entrance?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: For what belongs to this Staff let me alone. Come, where's this Bawd? where is ſhe?
sp.stage: All go towards my Lady Malory, and ſeeing it is ſhe they ſtart.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: My worthy Lady.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: My moſt worthy Lady.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Come, where's this Bawd here?
My moſt worthy Landlady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What have I to do with Ladies? 'Tis the Bawd that my Authority muſt cope withall.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Conſtable, you may make a Hobbyhorſe of your Painted ſtaff, and ride home again: Whip lye you there, and what ſay you to the Baſon?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: I ſay, 'tis a baſe one, and the Barberly Knave that owns it, they ſay his Wife had a Tooth drawn above, while he was trimming below, let him keep it for her an he will, for we have nothing to do with it,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Time's earneſt with me to be gone: farewel, you know my mind, perform it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With ſuch a zealous care as Saints the will of Heaven.

l.hi: The virtuous ſecret here Inclos'd I'll ſhow,
Since from pure fountains ſuch pure Rivers flow.

div.stage: Enter Barb. drest and Mr. William.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Hey ho! good truth this little practice of my Lady has lull'd me into ſo ſweet a fancy, that all this time I have been thus attyr'd i've thought my ſelf a very Lady; I would I were a very—

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Maid again, wouldſt thou not Barb?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Well, and I be not I may thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: What, thank me for't and cry? Come come, conceal't a little longer, and I'll warrant thee I'll find thee out a Father.

div.p: Here's one of the Fops already. Withdraw.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Mr. William, hiſt, do you hear? I have the worſt luck at Women, but I'll to her

sp.speaker: M. Will.
sp.p: What Mr. Gregory?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: The very ſame, Sir—your Lady's now gone in, may a man be ſo bold — you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will
sp.p: Faith not yet, but there's hopes you may ſee her anon.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I had a glimpſe of her, I cannot tell, but if my Father would but dye once.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: I marry Mr. Gregory, his Paſſing Bell were Muſick.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: The man that rung it ſhould not ſweat for nothing.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: A happy day, Mr. William, and as much (though my Rival) to the ſweet Mr. Gregory Dwindle.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Thanks ſweet Mr. Timothy Lyning

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: How's that Sir? — Lyning?

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: A conceit he has, witneſs your Worſhips Coat.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: 'Tis lyn'd indeed, and may lyne a Ladies Pettycoat, when ſuch a ſimple Gregory as thou ſhall dwindle but to hear on't.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: The dwindle in diſgrace?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Tell me of lyning.?—

sp.speaker: Mr. Wil.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen you come to ſee my Lady: which, if you kill one another, you'll hardly do, believe me.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: You have ſaid right, Mr. William, and had it not been for that—
I had, but it is no matter,—

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: And ſo had I — Puts up. but let that paſs —

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Well, an my Father would but dye once.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Gentlemen all, Good day: may we not in to the Lady?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: In to the Lady — you are ſomewhat raſh indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Enter the houſe I mean, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: She is now going forth to her Brother Sir Robert Malory; what favour ſhe may beſtow as ſhe paſſes I know not. But be not to tedeous, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Well, this melancholy Lady is a hard piece of matter to compaſs.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Some what ſtreight lac'd, Mr. Raſh.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: An I could but come to unlace her, I ſhould make her forget her mourning.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: We all aim at one mark — which only one muſt hit. I hope well.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: And I hope as well as you Sir.

div.stage: Enter Bab. and Mr. Will. as before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Have a care, you know my directions.
sp.stage: All the men complement her together.
sp.p: But one at once I beſeech you.
sp.stage: Pluſh whiſpers with Bab, ſhe ſhakes her head.

div.p: Mr. Pluſh has the ſtart of you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: We cannot help it, worthy Mr. William.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Hope well, and have well, the Motto of my Arms if ever I live to be Knighted, which if my Father would but dye once.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You would be a Fool in Folio.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: She ſhakes her head, what doth ſhe mean by that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: To hear him talk ſo like a humorous Coxcomb.
She has ſhook him off already.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I'll try my entertainment.
sp.stage: Gre. approches her after a great many of ridiculous complements.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I ſhall have my turn I hope anon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: 'Twere a very ill turn if you ſhould not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: There's the man, ſee how ſhe ſmiles upon him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: No here's the man, ſee how ſhe points at you.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: She points at me indeed; but oh thoſe ſmiles.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: That ſmile's a laugh, a ſcorn, a meer deriſion.
sp.stage: Gregory comes from her ſhaking his head amorouſly.
sp.p: Do you note his coming off, Sir, to her, to her?
sp.stage: Raſh goes to her complementing all the way.
sp.p: Sir, what news?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Nay, I ſay nothing, what it was it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: And what ſay you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: What ſhe ſaid ſhe ſaid.
sp.stage: Bab. claps her hand on her breaſt.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: That clapping of her hand upon her breaſt I do not like; ſhe gave me good words, but that's a tough bit on my ſtomach.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: I'll help you down with that, her words were theſe. 'Tis very true, you are a very civil Gentleman, and one above the fortunes which you ſeek; but when the heart is promis'd there's no calling back. Theſe were her words, believe me. Did ſhe not ſhake her head? as who ſhould ſay, you are the man muſt have her.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Tis enough.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You are muffled up in melancholy too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: She gave me comfortable words, but that embrace, and thus her hand meeting her heart ſo oft moves ſhe a little.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Then you'll be mov'd with nothing. I'll tell you what ſhe ſaid. Sir, you are a good man, a Citizen, wiſe and rich, though theſe three ſeldom go together

But when they do, it is an Aldermans pace. The Maidenhead is your Aims, and in your Arms believe me I wiſh one, for my Widowhood is otherwiſe engaged. Theſe were her words; you are the man muſt have her, did ſhe not ſmile upon you?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Why, why ſhould you be mayd then?
Look, he comes from her, and as melancholy as a ſick Munkey. You are the man, Mr. Gregory.
She bockons one of you.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Me, me, I hope, and I'll to her.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: You ſhall not go alone, Sir.

div.stage: Both go to her and whiſper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Now what's the happineſs?

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: My happineſs is, that what ſhe ſaid, ſhe ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You have had a long and a very gracious hearing.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I have, I thank her, a very gracious hearing. Why doth ſhe laugh ſo loud?
'Tis not at me I hope.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: At you? — no Sir, no, — what laugh at a civil Gentleman? I could tell you what ſhe ſaid for a need.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: I ſhould be glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Then I will make you glad, Sir, beſeech you hear me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pluſh.
sp.p: You are a proper man ſmooth and ſoft; you have not your name for nothing. I have heard you are valiant; fear no man, but the man that frights any man, a Serjeant; yet you have made ſome of them run, two or three at once, and glad they could overtake you too.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: This was a thing worth laughing at indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: But for Mr. Gregory the Country Gentleman (good harmleſs thing) ſhe ſaid little or nothing to him. I have told you what ſhe laughed at, you are the man muſt have her —
sp.stage: They fall off; Barb beckons Mr. Will.
sp.p: Your pleaſure, Madam.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: I cannot tell if ſhaking of the head, and ſerious ſhaking of the head, may be gracious ſign of love, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Oh ſmile, ſweet ſmile, full of ſplendidious rayes, ſuch as the Sun at Dinner time diſplays: if I do not tickle her in figure, let me be counted a Cypher; well, if my Father would but dye once, — I am the man muſt have her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Your will ſhall inſtantly be done ſweet Lady Gentlemen, 'tis my Ladies pleaſure you leave her at this time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pluſh,
sp.p:
my Lady deſires you to meet her exactly at Ten a clock this morning at the Devil Tavern, and there expect
her coming.
What diſcover your ſelf before theſe Coxcombs? Away, away, you are the man muſt have her.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Moſt beauteous Lady.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Mr. Gregory, I have ſent him off with a flea in his ear, onely that I might deſire you to meet her at the Devil exactly at ten a clock, in ſome diſguiſe for fear of a diſcovery; and ſhe'll not fail to meet you.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: At the Devil, ſaid you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Yes, yes, at the Devil Tavern, and there you'll find my Lady will be your Lady. Be gone.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Well, if my father would but die once, then—farewell moſt beauteous Lady.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Mr. Raſh, I have given him a Box to put his Pepper in; you are the man ſhall have her.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: In good deed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You'll hear as much from my Lady.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: O might I be ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Why you ſhall, Sir. I have told the Gentleman your mind, ſweet Lady, who deſires no greater happineſs on earth then to hear it from your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Mr. Raſh, though it ſcarce ſuit with modeſty, my bluſh begs excuſe; blame me not then for ſaying of that I love you, ſince 'tis a certrin truth, and ſuch a one as you deſire to hear, and therefore take your wiſh, you are the man ſhall have me.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: May I build?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: With Brick according to the Statute.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I mean upon this promiſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: O, you mean upon the Lady, Sir: you hear you may, the foundation is laid to your hands, and the Edifice half up already; and to complete the ſtructure my Lady would have you meet her in ſome diſguiſe at the Devil Tavern, at ten a clock exactly, and from thence to go with her to the next Chapel, and there be put in poſſeſſion of your greateſt Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I will not fail the time. Farewell, dear Lady. With this I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p:
Farewell, credulous Coxcomb; how eaſily are theſe Citizens gull'd, and how monſtrouſly do they gape for the bleſſing of a debauched Chambermaid? Any thing that has
not the nauceous name of a Cits. Darling is as modeſt as an Angel.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I hope to gratifie me for the pains and care I take in thus providing thee a wealthy Father and a fooliſh Husband: I may enjoy the bleſſing of your company.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I ſhall not derogate from the cuſtom of us Citizens, who long more for the company of a Gentleman Uſher, then a big-bellied woman for impoſſibilities; but you muſt be a Godfather.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver and the Captain as in the field.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Now, Knight, I ſee you love a noble promiſe too well to break it: y'are a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Sir, ſhould I find that I had loſt my ſelf in any thing that ſhould proclaim me leſs, I ſhould not hate my Enemy ſo much as ſuch a heady action.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I am ready.

sp.speaker: Sir. Ol.
sp.p: So ſudden; although I came to fight, yet were I ſure I could put by thy fury, the fighting part ſhould onely be thy own, mine onely my own Buckler.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Slighted; 's death prepare, or—

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: I muſt not dally then; Draws. come Mullineux

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I'm ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Hold, Captain, hold; you bleed.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: As you muſt do, or all my bloud's at hazard; come on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: How fatal, Sir, another cloſe may be we know not.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, nor do we fear it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Then, Mullineux, what following hurts you have call not the work of my unwilling hands, but thy frenzy. Captain, you faint

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Take your advantage then.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Advantage, Sir, how mean you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Of my wound.
My weakneſs, Bellingham.—You ſee there's now no interpos'd reſiſtance between my heart and thy bold weapon, come.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: I rather wiſh that all thy bloud were in thy veins again, though with that ſtrength, new courage, and the malice that but two minutes paſt purſued my life; you ſhould again purſue't, and put it to another dangerous hazard.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Thou art a noble Enemy—And now my troubled Underſtanding's calm again; I ſee my ſelf worthy the wounds I have, and all their anguiſh trebled—thou art juſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: I am too unmindful of thy wounds, thy ſmarting faintneſs—but my cares ſhall now onely attend thy ſafety.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Mind thy own—fly Bellingham.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Let all my beſt deſires be fruitleſs then; come, Mullineux, let me ſupport thy fainting body.

sp.speaker: Cap.

div.head: Act the Fourth.
div.stage: Enter old Thraſhard brave, and the Lady Malory.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: You know my mind; fail not in any thing that lies in my direction.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Fear not me; you have made me brave, and I'll do my buſineſs as bravely.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And ſo for your Son and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Nay for my Son, ſince he put on his bravery for a Gallant in jeſt, he will not be perſuaded but that he's a Gallant in earneſt; ſcorns to think on Canvas, courſe Frize, or a Sheepskin Doublet, or to talk but of Lords and Ladies. And as for my Daughter—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Heark, he's come already.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: In good Lady, 'tis his hum indeed.
If I can but hit the ſtate of a Juſtice handſomly.
But here comes Sir Robert, I muſt go to my ſtation.

div.stage: Thr. walks up and down in ſtate.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Well Edmonton, thou that holdſt her who holds me in the ſtrong net of Affection, I am once again come to ſee thee: how in th'imagination of this ſport my old heart capers? Well, this little houſe, this little cottage, while it holds my Peg is my beſt houſe, my Caſtle and my Palace of pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You are welcom, honeſt Gentleman; what would you?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Ha, what would you, Sir? By his face old Thraſhard my Tenant, but by the reverend outſide that he wears I know not with what ſtyle to ſalute him.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Would you ought with me or mine, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: I would ſpeak with Good man of the houſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: The Right Worſhipful Maſter of this houſe you may ſpeak to.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: What may I call your name?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: My name in common is Thraſhard, but with the Gentile Addition Oliver Threſhard Eſq Juſtice of Peace and Corum.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Juſtice of Peace and Corum—do you not know me, Mr. Oliver?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Not you Mr. what ſhall I call you? Belike you would have us know you whether we will or no, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Has not your Worſhip a ſon nam'd Abram?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: My Worſhip has a ſon that men call Mr. Abram Thraſhard.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: May a man deſire to ſee him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: He's not afraid to be ſeen, Sir—Son Abram, Mr. Abram.

div.p: Come, here's a Gentleman deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: To ſee me, my Right Worſhipful Father? if he be a Gentleman we are to be ſeen and ſpoke to. Your buſineſs to me, Sir?—hum—hum—hum—

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Doth your Worſhip know me, Mr. Abram?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: My Worſhip doth know many Gentlemen, ſome Lords and ſome Ladies too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: But me your Landlord, Sir Robert?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Landlord to one in Satten?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Your Worſhip remembers me, ſure Sir?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: My Worſhip remembers you not, Sir; muſt not, ſhall not, nor will not: Landlord to one in Satten! Did you hear him, Right worſhipful Father?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I heard him, my worſhipful ſon; juſt thus he talk'd to me too.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Landlord to one in Satten!

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: They talk of a wonderful Year, but here's a moſt wonderful Minute. I am ſure, worſhipful Sir, have not you a ſiſter call'd Gillian?

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Call'd Mrs. Gillian I have, and you ſhall know that I have: Siſter, Mrs. Gillian, Siſter.

div.p: There's a Gentleman would ſpeak with one Gillian, no more but ſo, plain Gillian.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: You might have remembred the M, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Which of the M's Madona Miſtreſs, or Maulkin?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Right worſhipful Father, ſhall our Greatneſs endure the Maulkin?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
