sp.p: I confeſs Forgetfulneſs: your pardon, ſweet Mrs. Gillian.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: 'Tis well you have chang'd your note, Sir; had you not, by this Chain I know what I know, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Do you know me, Mrs. Gillian?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: For a ſawcy Companion I do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Why this is admirable; what Brokers Wardrobe have they met withall? Let me not miſtake, and charge a kindneſs with unkindneſs though: for ought I know this may be ſome conceit, that in the cloſe ſhall to my entertainment adde more delight and luſtre. Worthy Sir, may but my boldneſs progreſs to the ſight of your fair Daughter Margaret, I have done, and reſt indebted to your Right worſhipful ſelf, and your worſhipful ſon and daughter.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Son Abram, call in your Right worſhipful ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Now talk like one of us, a Gentleman; a Gentlewoman ſhall talk with the Gentleman, and ſo as the Proverb is, 'Tis merry when Gentlefolks meet. Siſter, Mrs. Margaret, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your buſineſs, Brother.

sp.speaker: Abr:
sp.p: Ask our Right worſhipful Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: I there's the ſtar that uſhers in my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: My beauteous Margaret, how ere o'th'ſudden chang'd into theſe rich clothes, I hope you know me better then your father doth, your brother, or your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Know you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: I hope you do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed I do not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Not know me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No; —nor to be brief and plain do I deſire to know you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Not know me, I am Sir Robert Malory.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir Robert Malory? I do not know him; but I have heard of ſuch a one, a Knight, a City Knight, a piece of old dry ſtuff that's good for nothing, yet as luſtful as a Satyr: out upon him, wrongs his good Lady, ſuch a beauteous Lady, nay ſuch a virtuous Lady; out upon him. They ſay his Luſt moſt eagerly purſues his Tenants Daughter, a poor Country Innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Ha, this the delight I look'd for?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis reported he has done her good, ſettled a poor Eſtate upon her aged Father; and of goodneſs muſt the reward be ſin?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Some Conjuration, Witchcraft.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How he ſweats?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Siſter, Pray call our mother.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Lady Mother.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: How's this? her mother? why this is my Lady, or the Devil in her likeneſs; I'm ſure ſhe'll know me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Deſire to ſpeak with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: You Lady, will ſhe not know me neither?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I cannot ſtand to talk, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Not with me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: With you, Sir? no, Sir? what are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Ha, do you not know me, Lady?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Know you, Sir? how? when? where? why? for what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: How? when? where? why? for what, Sir? why here's the fineſt mad fit, the moſt worſhipful piece of Lunacy, that a man ſhall deſire to look on: why, are not you my wife?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Thy wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: My wife.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I hope, my Right worſhipful Husband, you will not ſee me jeer'd and derided; he challenges me for his wife.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: My Lady your wife? By this Chain if you play the mad Alderman here, you were better have done it in Bedlam. Your wife? Go to, no more but ſo, go to.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: Our Right worſhipful mother your wife? By this Satten go to, no more but ſo, go to.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Methinks in ſuch a Gentleman as you are, ſuch ſport, ſo old, and ſuch a reverend man, this wildneſs ſhews not handſom.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Handſom quotha, my wife deny me too? If I be mad, I'll play the mad mans part a little longer. Heark Lady, are not you my wife? are not you my Tenant? are not you Abram Ninne? you Gillian of Brainford? you pretty Peg of Edmonton? and this houſe here my own? 's death they jeer me. This is a trick of my Ladies, to deride and ſhame me: ſhe has diſcovered me, and there's no hiding of my faults. Peg, wife Peg, I confeſs my love; but do you hear me, Lady? Madam Peg.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The old man's mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: I were mad indeed if I ſhould not know my own Lady: prethee torment me no longer. I was wanton I confeſs it, and bluſh to own I was ſo; but by this free confeſſion I hope to gain your pardon.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: When we walk thus abroad, how our once familiar Acquaintance will bow and adore our Satten? but we know the worſhipful nod, for a word we ſhall hardly afford them.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: May I believe all this you have proteſted? well, but yet you may make Relapſes, how ere the fault is pardoned.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: My thanks, and promiſe ne'r to dote again on her, nor any other. How likes the Right worſhipful this now?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: By this Chain exceeding well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: I proteſt by this Satten it is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Pleaſe your Worſhips may I poſſeſs her now? Do you know me now?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Our worthy and right worſhipful Landlord.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Will your Satten ſubmit to that, Sir? Peg, I love thee, not for thy Beauty but thy Vertues. The teſtimony of it ſhall be this; your ſtates ſhall be as great as they appear to be, I have ſpare bags will do it; and my care ſhall find you out a worthy Husband. Right worſhipful Tenant, I give you the Houſe and Lands you live in, and to maintain your ſelves and them with credit an hundred pounds a year, and after your deceaſe it paſſes to your Heirs, from thence to their Poſterities.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Thanks to our Right worſhipful Landlord.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p:
For you't ſhall be my care and ſtudy to find out a juſt and fit reward to crown your Vertues.
This conquest gain'd, rewards are due to thoſe
Who make ſuch acts as theſe their greateſt foes.

div.stage: Three Tables are ſet out; Enter Gregory Dwindle diſguis'd as in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: This is the place I am to meet my Lady in, and near the hour too; but I wonder ſhe would chuſe a Tavern! Perhaps ſhe loves Sack before Matrimony, if ſhe doth ſo do I; therefore, ſweeet Mr. Gregory, ſit down and recreate your ſelf.
sp.stage: Sits down and knocks; Enter Drawer.
sp.p: A Bottle you conceive me of the beſt Canary; and if a Lady come pray ſend her in.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What Lady, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: That's counſel, but for ſatisfactions ſake 'tis a Mourning Lady.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: You are miſtaken in the houſe, Sir; here's none but mad Ladies come hither.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: She may be a mad mourning-Lady, for ought I know. If my Father would but dye once, how happy ſhould I be!

div.stage: Enter Drawer with Wine, and Pluſh diſguis'd.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: If the Lady comes, you know my mind; I'm in the Figure Three.
sp.stage: Sits down; Draw. fills to Gre. and then goes to Pluſh.
sp.p: I am for Canary: but what fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: A Country Gentleman, Sir, that ſtayes here for a Lady.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Not perfectly, but I gueſs ſome Madonna or other that haunts our houſe: we have all conveniencies.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: This Sack would taſt better if my Father were but dead once, but as it is, it is.

div.stage: Enter Drawer with wine, and Raſh diſguis'd.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: You know the token?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Raſh, I do, and ſhall obſerve it.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: But what two fellows are they? I would be private.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Two Town Bullies, that call here commonly once a day, to drink a Bottle; their ſtay will not be long.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: But why aſunder?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: For fear of quarrelling, Sir; men of ſuch known valour are commonly at variance.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: Another Room would ſerve me better; I am not fit for Bullies.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: You need not fear them, Sir, they dare not fight a ſtranger.
sp.stage: Draw. goes to Pluſh, and fills out a Glaſs, Raſh ſits down, Draw. comes to him.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: I am for Sack.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: This Sack is very powerful, for methinks, I could fight now; ſa, ſa, ſa.
sp.stage: Draws, and fences up toward Raſh.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, hold; I beſeech you hold: let not me be the object your rage points at.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: What, Mr. Raſh, are you here? I'gad we are the happy men, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: I think ſo too, Mr. Gregory: put up, put up, and let's drink a health to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: With all my heart, and ſing a health to her too, if my Father would but dye once.

sp.speaker: Raf.
sp.p: Now you talk of ſinging, let's have a ſinging health, to paſs away time, till the Lady comes.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: With all my heart, but as for Mr. Pluſh he may hide his face like a velver lining: we are the happy men.
sp.stage: Mr. Pluſh dances up and down, at laſt comes to Gre. and Raſh.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: What, Mr. Raſh, and Mr. Gregory Dwindle!

sp.speaker: Gre. and Raſ.
sp.p: What, Mr. Raſh, are you here too?

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: So it feems, and I fear we are all ſent hither to be made Coxcombs of, for I ſee no Lady appears.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: That may be, however I'l be merry, and ſing a ſong, and drink a bottle; and a Pox of Melancholy, my Father muſt dye, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Mr. Gregory, hang ſorrow, I ſay: let's have the ſong.

l.hi: Here is without doubt
Two Fools and a Lout,
Who came out of hopes to be merry or mad.
But I gad their delight
Has ſham'd 'em out right,
And has made the poor Citizen ſad.
But let her be dam'd, and be wretched, and poor,
I'l drink till I'm drunk, and be jilted no more.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: What ſay you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I'm of your mind.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Then ſhow your ſelves true ſons of the Pitcher, and roar out the two laſt lines.

q.l: Then let her be damn'd, for ſhe's wretched and poor.
We'l drink till we're drunk, and be jilted no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p:
Good morrow, Gentlemen, you may wonder my Lady choſe out this place to meet in; but when you know the reaſon, you'l rather praiſe than blame her. She knows you are
valiant all, you for the Sword, you for the Law, and you, Sir, for the antient weapon, Fiſt.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: By your favor, Sir, I am for the Modern Weapon, Sword too, if I am provok'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: It may be ſo, Sir, therefore my Lady knowing your exceſſive Valors, and deſiring to have no Innocents blood ſhed in her cauſe, deſires you to drink for her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: He that drinks moſt, and finds the neweſt Health, my Lady vows to marry.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: Say you ſo? nay for drinking and ſo forth, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: And me for drinking, drabbing, ſwearing, fighting, dancing, ſinging, and huffing, let me alone, and if here are not Graces enough to win a Widow, the Devil ſhall turn husband.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: And let me alone for— if my Father would but dye once.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: If I might adviſe you, Mr. Gregory, drink out of a Boot.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: A Boot?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Yes, a Boot, and one of the largeſt you can meet withall. 'Tis new, and a ſufficient Jeſt to win a Lady.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I can do it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You need not fear the Lady then.
sp.stage: Enter Draw. Greg. whiſpers the Draw.
sp.p: Out of a ſhoe, Mr. Pluſh, I think would take with her, for I once heard her ſay, ſhe ſaw the frolick, and it pleas'd her ſtrangly.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: It ſhall be done, Sir.
sp.stage: Pluſh whiſpers the Drawer, who Exits: Mr. Will. aſide to Raſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: A bottle ſerves your turn, that being off leave the two Fops, and come down ſtairs, where you ſhall find my Lady ready to receive you.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: Thanks, Mr. William, let this reward your care.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I muſt be gone, my Lady waits below to hear of your ſucceſs, and whoe're gets the victory, let his loud voice proclaim it. Farewell.

div.stage: Enter Drawer, with a Boot full, Shoe full, and a Bottle full of Wine; gives the Boot to Greg. the Shoe to Pluſh, and the Bottle to Raſh.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: I ſee, Gentlemen, you are reſolv'd to out-do me: if I loſe the Lady for want of drinking, 'tis my ill fortune, howe'r here's to her, and to that happy man who has her.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: And here's a health to the unhappy man who goes without her.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: And here's a health to the leg, foot, and perſon that in former ages wore this famous Boot.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: This ſhoe has a deviliſh hogo with it: Eſſence of toes! how I admire you.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: This boot has as profound an underſtanding as my Lady, and becauſe I deſire to know the depth of one as well as the other; thus I ſqueeſe the Pitcher, over Shoes, over Boots, I ſay.
sp.stage: Both having drunk, hollow, and reel up and down, crying a Dwindle, a Pluſh, a Pluſh, a Dwindle, &c.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Gregory Dwindle, Fop out of Mode, and Monſter of the Town, dare you preſume to think you've won the Lady?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Timothy Facing, Fop Alamode, and Pimp to half the Nation, dare you preſume to think you've won the Lady?

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Yes, and to ſhow I dare, thus I aſſault you.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: And in return, I'l bootifie your Honour.
sp.stage: Throws the Boot at Pluſh; both draw and fight at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Dwindle, thou haſt wrong'd me.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Pluſh, thou haſt wrong'd me.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Thou haſt not won the Lady.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Thou haſt not won the Lady.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: For which— though I am loth.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: For which— though I am loth: but yet I muſt, my Honour cannot brook it.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Mr. Gregory, I believe we are both chous'd: what's become of Raſh?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Pox of our raſh doings, how ſoon might one of us two have been nothing. But what's become of Raſh?

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Sneak'd after the Lady, on my life.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: O that the Raſcal were but dead once, how I would maul him for all his skill in Law.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Will. Mr. Raſh, and Barbary as Married.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Oh, horror, revenge, revenge.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Blood and revenge aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, but revenge, revenge, I ſay.
sp.stage: Gre. and Pluſh, rave up and down.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: They quarrel for your beauty, Lady.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Lady me no Ladies, for I'll be a Lady no longer, I am my Ladies Chamber-maid. Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: If you know her not yet, you may know her anon by this, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: By that, Sir. What Sir? Villany, villany, &c.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: No matter for that, I'll be honeſt enough to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Pox of your honeſty. Villany, villany, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: You cannot fly ſo faſt, but I can follow.—

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Blood and revenge, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: I, I, blood, and revenge, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Fie Gentlemen, be patient, you are miſtaken, and the loſs you rave for ſo is but imaginary. Did you not ſee the Jeſt?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I ſaw the Jeſt, that is, I ſaw Raſh, and my Lady, hand in hand; But blood, and revenge, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, it was Bab, my Ladies Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: How! my Ladies Chamber-maid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: The Lady is a Diſh for your ſelf to Feaſt on, Mr. Gre.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Is't poſſible? Gull him with the maid, to help me to the Bed of the Miſtriſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You ſee my love, Sir? He's a fooliſh Remnant-ſeller, and a Citizen: you are a Gentleman. Hark in your ear, meet her within this hour, at the Chappel in Dukes-Place.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I ſhall have her then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You need not doubt it.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Well, if my Father would but dye once!

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Be gone, be gone, Sir, you'll loſe the time elſe.
—Now for you, Mr. Pluſh, my Lady deſires you to meet her within this two hours, at Hide-Park corner; from thence to go to Knights-Bridge, and there Enter into thoſe pleaſing Bonds, call'd Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: Shall I have her then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You ſhall but miſs not a hair of my Directions, hark, — be gone.—

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: I will not fail, I cannot chuſe but laugh at the poor Citizen, a Chambermaid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Laugh on, at length I ſhall have all the cauſe, and bleſs my ſelf, thus happily to end, the troubles were begun in one nights pleaſure, methinks I'm a Gallant all over: and glory as much in making other men Father my Children, as they do in Marrying their Debauch'd Miſſes to their ſervants, thus far I'm ſafe: Dwindle muſt Marry my Lady Antiquity; but who Mr. Pluſh? Oh I have it: Thraſhard has a ſcolding Daughter, and one, who as much longs for a Husband, as he does for a Wife. Her I'll ſeduce to meet him: if not the perſon, the Eſtate will move her.

l.hi: Then all who ſmile to ſee Intrigues well done,
For love, or honour, will Applaud this one.

div.head: ACT the Fifth.
div.stage: Enter Raſh like a Puritan, running, and Bab like a Puritan, following him.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: KEep off, I ſay, do not purſue the faithful: haſt thou not already Metamorphoz'd me from a man, into a Monſter? from a Reverend Citizen, into a diſhonorable Badg of Antiquity? I feel the horns, yea the very horns of the Beaſt as it were rebel againſt the Fleſh, and tell me I am transform'd.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: From a Monſter, to a Saint? Ah conſider what a vile Trade you follow'd, how you Cheated this, that, and to'ther Friend, and all for want of the true light, which now is plentifully beſtow'd upon thee.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: A true light one you were indeed, and ſo I fear will prove; But have a care, conſider, I may reform, I may find out the ill turnings, the evil meanings, and the ſinful doings of the Brethren; and then reaſſuming my ſo late loſt Religion, be advanc'd the Cities head, and, as one of its grave Fathers has already ſacrific'd the Devil and the Pope, and other the leſs faulty, and harmleſs ſinners of the Age; I may bend all my fury towards you, and with my ſword of deſtruction, which is the Beam of Juſtice, ſweep ye all into that honorable Manſion, Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Oh horrid! —canſt thou name that place, and not tremble? Or think you that common ſewer of Sin, and not deſpiſe the founder. Bridewell? Oh horror! A common Bawdy-houſe, and made for the entertainment of none but looſe, looſe Women, call'd by the vulgar Whores.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: 'Twas built for thee, baſe Woman; But the ſpirit's weak, and vexation deſires a Reſting place, I muſt ſit down.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Alaſs, poor ſpirit, I will ſit down too, and keep thee company, even in tribulation.

div.stage: Enter as Married Gregory and old Gent. vaild: after them a Boy with Wine.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: The buſineſs is done, now Widow, and there's no frowning. Come, come, I am the happy man, and ſo forth. —Boy, ſome Wine, — here's a health to that Monſtrous Coxcomb Raſh.—
sp.stage: Drinks and flings the remainder in Raſh's Face.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Oh, moſt Diabolical! my zeal pricks me, to give them ſome dehorting words of Exhortation. Hum, hum.—

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Come, come, I ſay, you ſhall drink, drink and be drunk, Lady, and then.—

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Where are you Reeling, d'ye think, you profane abuſer?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Why you blind Coxcomb, to a Tavern. Do you hear, Monſter? if you will drink you may, if not, you ſee this.—

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: No, I ſmell a Satan in it, I defie thee, do what thou dar'ſt.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Aminadab, I will beat thee into one Spunge, and then cut thee into pieces, Hypocrite, unleſs you will do as I do, that is drink, and ſo forth. Will you take?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: No, I will firſt turn Martyr, and take my affliction patiently, 'tis the oath of the Brethren.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: And this is the Oath of the Hectors.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Do, ſtrike, I am arm'd with ſpiritual armor.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Ceaſe, wicked man, to perſecute the faithful. Theſe are not ſtripes of Love. Alas, poor man he melts: and I in pitty muſt relent for company. —

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Well, Sir, the Brethren will meet, and then.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Then I will beat them too, and ſo commend me to um. Come along, Widow.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: My zeal muſt find revenge, this perſecution I find is the Badge of the Brethren.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Will. like a Quaker.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Welcome, dear brother, how have you fought within this Wordly warfare?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Not without great danger of Satans devices, but being confidently Arm'd with the Spirit, I came off without any corporal harm, yet I ſuffered notwithſtanding, the perſecution of a ſword, and had that Helliſh liquor Sack moſt ſcornfully flung into my Eyes, which made my zeal grow hot to revenge me of my perſecutors.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: It was well done, and ſhow'd the ſtoutneſs of a Brother. The Element is good, if in the hands of a zealous Brother: which makes me ſeldome be without it, I have found great comfort in a cup of Sack.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: I profeſs, Brother, you ſay right.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: The Bottle is full, I drink of it to fire my zeal, which is many times apt to grow cold; will it pleaſe you to taſt of it?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: I thank you, and will participate, — truſt me, Drinks. 'tis very good, and my ſpirit moves me to try the Drinks again. Depth of it.— verily, verily, 'tis very comfortable, the very Emblem of water of life.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p:
How ſoon is this credulous Couple deluded? by this means I hope to make both Friends,
In Zeal, in Drink, and Weddings, all have ends.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: It is indeed the very Water of life.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: I I, therefore the Brethren uſe it, truſt me Brother, it recover'd Mrs. Simple, that was ſtruck into a viſion, and wakened her ſo contentedly, as if ſhe had ſeen but a dream, it was at a Sermon of one Mr. Thumps.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Indeed I knew him, he was ſilenc'd, becauſe he broke a new Pulpit. A very painful man, and much given to labour and Travel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: You ſay right, he doth much good upon the fiſters; but as I was inform'd, he was ſilenc'd for waking a Uſurer that was a ſleep.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: No, no, it was a Church-warden believe me; but have you any more of this Liquor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Yea, for the faithful, I have.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Ananias, take ſome of this, 'tis good to digeſt affliction.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Truly, Spouſe, thy counſel is at this time very comfortable.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: After adverſity, proſperity hath a pleaſing taſt. May I participate?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p:
Yea,—and much good
Drinks and then gives it to Mr. Will. who drinks all off. may it do unto thy ſpirit. Is it all off?—'Tis pitty.—Now, Spouſe, let us go unto thy Woman, thy deceitful Woman, who hath abuſed the faithful, but I forgive her.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: And I, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Thus far I'm ſafe and every thing ſucceeds according to my wiſh. Now Bab, thou haſt a Husband, and one that's made of Wax, and as fit to take any impreſſion, as his zeal is to follow any Religion; But how you came ſo altered is a Riddle, and one too deep for me to Conſter. By this time all my Clients are Married, from the Fop to the Courtier, from the Courtier to the Clown, and from the Clown to the Preciſian. All's done, and ſafely, thanks to my happy Stars.

l.hi: What I ſhall get by this Prodigious Birth,
Is yet unknown, all I deſire is mirth.

div.stage: SCENE Drawn, Diſcovers the Captain in a Chair, Sir Oliver diſguis'd like the Doctor, Sir Robert, Lady Mallory, and the Lady Lovely weeping.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: How is't, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith a weak man, Sir Robert.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Nay, nay Siſter then I ſhall chide you. Weeping? Come, come, dry your eyes, you've wept too much already.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Had I thought to come, had been to meet this new occaſion, I tell you plainly, you'd come alone for me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That 'tis my fault, ſo many tears are ſhed, I cannot but acknowledge, and could my death, which once I thought more certain far than life, make reparation for that raſh act, of which, I, wretched I, was Author, you ſoon ſhould find an ample ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: It was not that we came for; but hearing that worthy Gentleman, Sir Oliver, upon this bloody accident was fled, we came to know the certainty from you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He fled. To ſtop his flight, I gave him what incouragement I could, told him my wounds were nothing, and proclaim'd the hand of Noble Bellingham, as white as innocency. Do you ſee this Ring, your tears will hardly let you ſee it, yet Ladypray look upon it. Can you call to mind a former ſight on't?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I have ſeen it ſure, Sir Oliver's, I take it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Lady, 'twas.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What comfort yields the ſight on't?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have ſhewn this, to acquit me of thoſe Treacherous thoughts, that you ſuſpected in me, 'gainſt the life of Noble Bellingham, who as he parted to take a journy in uncertain Paths, left this Ring with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: You have charm'd us now from all our harſh ſuſpitions.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
I do not grive ſo much, this loſs of blood, nor all the ſmart goes with it, as by this I have loſt the ſight and the ſociety of ſuch a fair Example of all goodneſs; I could tell you how much beyond the ſufferings of a man,) I dar'd him to the field, how meeting there, he did not look upon me as a Foe, but took into his Embraces my wounded body, brought me from the field, and to the diligence, and well known skill of this good man
did leave me, and with him his ample ſatisfaction for my cure, or whatſoever might be demanded.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Sir, you have given him a fair Character.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He were baſer than Envy that would not; and all this he did i'th' honour of your Beautiful Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro,
sp.p: Lady!

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Dear Siſter.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He lov'd you dearly; can his praiſes then offend your Ear?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No; Every ſyllable of his commendations is Muſick; but to think that for my ſake, his much commended worth ſhould thus be loſt, O I could weep my ſelf into a ſenſeleſs ſtatue, O Bellingham, O Noble, Noble Bellingham! No hope again to ſee him?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do you wiſh it?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: As life, or health, or Heaven.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You will not then deny one kindneſs to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: What is't, Captain?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Only this, Sir Robert, I would beg ſince ſhe deſires to ſee him, the favour to wear this Diamond, until I find fit time to ſend it to him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Send it?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, no ſtrict enquiries of me, if you dare truſt me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But direct me, Sir, I'll carry't him my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You know my boſom, Lady, if you will ſend it?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Take it, Captain.—But,

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I conceive all that you can urge me to, and will perform it to your own wiſh.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But why returns not Bellingham? Or doth he (hearing his goodneſs has Inthrald my heart,) neglect me now, 'cauſe I neglected him, when my freſh griefs inforc'd me? If he do I muſt confeſs it but a juſt revenge: and ſo as long as grief ſhall give me leave, I'll patiently indure it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But you ſhall not, you have indur'd beyond a Womans ſtrength, and ſhall indure no longer. Mr. Doctor, you are the man muſt Cure her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Diſcovers himſelf, —Beautious Lady, 'twas your command I ſhould not trouble you with any tedious Love-ſuit; and you ſee I've done what you injoyn'd me, now I hope, I have your voluntary grant?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am now what Noble Bellingham ſhall pleaſe to make me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: No doubt but he'l make much of thee, Siſter, wilt thou not, Knight? My brave Sir, of a thouſand per annum.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: She's now my own, and in this union, Sir, the beſt delights that her deſires would have, are mine, my own, and I ſhall ſo purſue 'um.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: The news with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Your Tenant Thraſhard having information you and your Lady, were come to viſit your melancholy Siſter, By way of thanks and gratitude for your laſt kindneſs, has brought ſome of his Neighbouring Shepherds, to preſent you with a Dance.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: He's welcome, and if it be no trouble to you, Siſter, give them admittance,

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You may command me, Brother.

div.stage: Muſick within, they all ſit down, then Enter Thraſhard, Abram, Margaret, and Five more dreſt like Shepherds and Shepherdeſſes, they Dance. After the Dance, they Sing.

l.hi: Charming Beauty, you whoſe Eyes
Delight in love and ſacrifice:
Since your Glories ſhine ſo bright,
Let no ſorrows make it night,
Baniſh all the griefs away,
While delights about you play.
For the Pleaſures of youth, and the Joys of your Bliſs,
Is to Frolick, Admire, to Revel, and Kiſs.

lg.l: Cho. For the, &c.

l.hi: The ſweets of your life, on that Union doth wait,
Immortaliz'd Joys are the bleſſings of Fate:
The Gods though made drunk with their pleaſures above,
Think nothing Diviner, than that of your Love;
For love to exceſs, by injoyment made ſtrong,
Makes Mortals immortally frolick along,
In delights uncontroul d, like the powers above,
We ſurfeit and faint with the pleaſures of love.

lg.l: Cho. In delights, &c.

l.hi: Each paſſionate look, and each melting embrace,
Each glory attending the charms of your face,
So ſubtly attracts, and ſo ſtrongly commands,
We are ſlaves being free, and free when in bands.
Unkindneſs in frowns, the mandate of hate,
Makes Hell of what Heaven Decreed for our fate.
But you in this Empire ſo tutelar prove,
That Angels are ſubjects, and fight for your love.

lg.l: Cho. But you in, &c.

div.stage: Song ended, they dance: after the dance, enter Raſh, Bab, and Mr. William.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Tenant and Friends, we thank you, and aſſure your ſelves it ſhan't go unrewarded: but now to Church; nay we'l not loſe a minute.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: I beſeech you ſtay a little, there's more mirth in your way, and ſuch as I dare promiſe will be worth the looking on: ſee, it appears.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Who's this, Mr. Raſh?

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: The ſame, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Your ſuit continued ſtill, Sir?

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: I have turn'd up another ſuit now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Your Wife!

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: Even ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Verily ſo, Sir.—Do not you know me, Lady?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Truth, not I.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Nor you, nor you, nor you?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: We know thee not. What art thou?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: This 'tis to put off our vain and ſuperfluous colours, and to walk as becometh the zealouſly metamorphos'd. I was your creature, Lady.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How? my creature!

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p:
In the phraſe of the world 'twas ſo, but I am now my own, yet verily I do err, for no wife is her own diſpoſer, verily
none, for we, to affirm ſincerely, are but members of our head, the man our ſpouſe and our ſuperior.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How, Bab?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: The ſame, believe me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How comes ſhe to ſpeak in the noſe ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: The tone of the Brethren; but what do you think of this member, Bab?

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Though begot, and conceiv'd in vanity, yet being born in the ſtate of Matrimony, the offence may no doubt be remitted, and the innocent in time may prove a moſt zealous member.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And what think you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: I think as my wife thinks, for man and wife are one.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: Verily you have ſaid, and ſaid like a zealous husband.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Much joy betide your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: I thank you. For having this Beauty, I have all the joys my auſpicious Stars could give me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Well, Gregory, if you do hang your ſelf—

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Why, if he does, he does, we cannot help it, we are now man and wife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: For better, for worſe.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Then for better, for worſe, I will keep her; why there's another Rival of mine, Sir Oliver; ſay he ſhould take the ſame Journey, and go to Heaven in a halter after him, can I help it?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I confeſs you cannot, thank you, Mr. Pluſh.

sp.speaker: Pluſh.
sp.p: I did but ſay, if you ſhould, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: No, though the loſs be ſomewhat grievous to me, the ſorrow ſhall not go ſo deep, ſhe's yours.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: As ſure as the Church can make her.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: What muſt be, muſt be, Sir; much joy betide you.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Thank you.

div.stage: Enter Gregory, and Old Gentlewoman veil'd.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Now, Lady, in ſpight of all my Rivals, you are mine.

sp.speaker: Old. Gentlew.
sp.p: I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I know you are, and thereupon—

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Not a kiſs, till you come to your Chamber, and then ſhe's your own all over.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: 'Tis enough: now if my Father would but die once.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: When Pluſh ſhall hear of this, he'l hang himſelf.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: If he do make a wry mouth at the match, I cannot help it, I ſhould not do ſo by him though.
Save you, Gentlemen, we have the Lady.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: We have the Lady, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Is my Siſter divided between you?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: You cannot both have the Lady.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Alas, poor Gregory.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Alas, poor Pluſh.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Alas, poor Coxcombs: here's a coil indeed about a worthleſs ſhadow: what am I, Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Alas, poor Gregory,—Alas poor Pluſh.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Why, who have I then?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Why, who do you think you have? this is no Ivy-buſh, nor I an Owl. D'ye ſtare upon me?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: My daughter Gillian!

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: What my ſiſter Gillian! I thought by her ſcolding, ſhe would be a Lady.

sp.speaker: Pluſ.
sp.p: Are you my wife?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: I cannot tell, how do you think, Sir, ha?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: Come, Sir, be contented, ſhe's young and handſome, and no doubt will prove a fortune to you. But what ſay you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Why, I ſay, I know not what to ſay, ſhe is not very old, is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: In her Hood, ſome fifty, but in ſome other dreſſings ſhe has, ſhe may paſs for a thing of twenty.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Here be ſome Gutters, Channels, and long Lanes, but being fill'd up with a little Plaſter of Paris, the face may paſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro.
sp.p: For a Paris-Garden face it may, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlw.
sp.p: Come, ne're be melancholy, you ſhall find a woman of me, I'l warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt like a good old Gentlewoman. Well, an my wife would but die once.

sp.speaker: Old Gentlew.
sp.p: How, ſweet-heart? your Father.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I know what I ſaid, I'l warrant you, if my wife would but die once.

sp.speaker: Mr. Will.
sp.p: Come, you are ſo melancholy; why here's a man ſuffers as much as you▪ or you, Mr. Pluſh and yet you ſee he's patient.

sp.speaker: Raſ.
sp.p: I thought I had married a Lady too, but by Lady there is no ſuch matter, we muſt be contented now though.

l.hi: You that languiſh'd ſo long for thoſe whom you find,
Have kindneſs for you, like the reſt of man-kind,
Though Love and that cheat no man can indure,
Yet be conſtant and kind, tho they're falſe and unſure,
For in time you'l have ſomething to eaſe a ſad heart,
The pleaſure to think how your Rivals do ſmart.
Here's a Brother, a Fop, and a country Clown;
A Siſter, a Scold, and a Jilt of the Town:
Theſe Babbies of Grace, to be faithful, as yet,
Reſolve to debauch, by the Rules of the Writ.
To increaſe without fear of a monſtrous preamble,
And hold forth to all they ſhall meet in their ramble.
To be faithful and true, are the Rules they admire:
To oblige ev'ry Brother, and quench ev'ry fire,
Theſe Lambs of a Fold, like young Adamites move,
Make Text their enjoyment, Religion their love:
In a Pulpit they'l melt, like a Spark in a Coach,
Thump the Cuſhion and Preach, though they're big with debauch.

sp.speaker: Bab.
sp.p: You may abuſe the faithful, who are big with Grace and Labour, and rail againſt thoſe careful Shepherds, who ſtrive with the ſweat of their brows to keep their Flocks from ſtraying, you may. —
sp.stage: From the time that Pluſh and Gillian enter'd, the Captain entertains Margaret in dumbſhow till now.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Token I remember, and that after this Ladies Marriage I gave it thee, with a promiſe, If ever I liv'd to come aſhore again, never to marry other.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Heav'n, I ſee, is juſt in ev'ry thing, and would not let me violate that Faith I had given up to thee. And ſince it has preſerv'd me from a Fate ſevere as was my Merit: thus I make good my promiſe; Which is thy Father?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then to him I kneel, hoping he'l be ſo truly kind to give me his conſent.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Captain, take it, you are a worthy Gentleman, and much deſerve a better fortune.

sp.speaker: Abr.
sp.p: What another Lady of the Family of the Thraſhards! nay then I feel Honour creeps on apace, and I may be a Lord. Your ſervant, Brothers; nay I am bold, but 'tis my ambition to be acquainted with Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And you are welcome, we both are Brothers now.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob.
sp.p: Why, God a mercy, Captain, now I love you dearly; and to expreſs how much I dote upon you, let's have a Dance, and then we'l move to Church, where I will play the Father.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

l.hi: Never was day ſo doubly bleſt before,
Contemn'd by one, I found what I adore.
Double Affection too doth crown the End:
Finding a Miſtreſs, I have found a Friend.
Honour to ſuch exceſs, in you I've found,
Love, Virtue, Merit, it at once has crown'd.
Your Generoſity ſo highly mov'd,
By all the World you ought to be belov'd.
When friendſhip to ſuch height doth act its part,
At once you conquer, body, ſoul, and heart.
YOu did expect ſome bawdy Farce to day,
Some glorious nonſenſe, or a thundring Play,
Enough to fright the huſſing Wits away:
But you are cheated, and inſtead of either,
We've tyr'd your patience with Harangue of neither.
How pleaſant 'twas to ſee ſome ſleep i' th' Pit,
Some ſerious Judges, and there dream of Wit,
Awake, I'm ſure they never thought of it.
Some in a corner 'mongſt the num'rous crowd
It ſeems were pleas'd, they laugh'd ſo monſtrous loud;
'Twas not at Play, but Beauty under cloud.
D— me, ſays one▪ ſhe's handſome, wondrous fair;
Another, rot the Jilt, if two compare
In notes together, all the Pit deſpair.
Then humming round the creature yet unknown,
They court her to-unmask, that being done,
Their ſtomachs nauſeate, and their love grows cool,
And all retire from unregarded fool.
We have no charms t' attract your face this way,
No gawdy Cloaths, nor Scenes to grace our Play.

lg.l: Here you muſt be content with yea and nay.

l.hi: But let that paſs: be kind, Gallants, for fear,
Through me your double dealings do appear.
I'm grown preciſe, a Siſter, and a Saint,
Lay'd by the Trade of Chamber-maid and Paint.
The lewd vocation of informing Cully,
Your Miſs admits th' Amours of ſuch a Bully.
They meet in private, and to tell you truly,

lg.l: This night th' intrigue is done with Betty B—

l.hi: Then Spark, deſpiſing all his Miſtreſs charms,
Perhaps, takes me into his longing Arms;
With patience leaves what was before his right,
And all to ſhun the danger of the fight.
But roaring Huff for ſuch affronts will cry,
D— me, the Raſcal and the Jilt ſhall die.
But this is paſt, I am a Convert grown,
Abhor the lewd devices of the Town.
Move as the humor moves, ſometimes be bold,
A Shepherd may debauch in his own Fold.
The Lambs ſometimes muſt play; ſhou'd they be dull,
A Siſter ne're wou'd get her belly full.
Am I not happy then, in my new bands?
Gallants, do you confirm it with your hands.
Iſee your looks prognoſticate a ſtorm,
And if you pleaſe, your Quaker ſhall reform.
Religious Players, in this wicked Age,
Appear like Devils, and diſgrace the Stage:
Thoſe ſerious Fops have ruin'd all our pains.

lg.l: To ſhun our Houſe will make a Saint of Haynes.
